options.A: female patient fell from a height of 3 meters while cleaning her house and presents with severe headache and nausea. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?

question_text: An elderly patient presented with fluctuating levels of consciousness. Which of the following should be done?

options.A: Metabolic panel screen

question_text: Which of the following is a therapeutic effect of mannitol?

options.A: Decreased mean arterial pressure

patient with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) followed by midline shift had an EVD inserted and then developed signs of infection. Blood and CSF cultures were sent. You want to start empirical treatment. What should you do?
patient on warfarin develops intracranial hemorrhage. What is the next step? (No PCC in answers)

patient with head trauma arrives at the emergency department conscious and oriented. After one hour, he loses consciousness and has a dilated right pupil. What abnormality would you expect to see on a brain CT?

question_text: What is a potential complication of using hypertonic saline in the treatment of increased ICP?

options.A: Cerebral edema

question_text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency department by his family after they found him unresponsive in bed. The last time he was seen well was 1 day ago. A CT scan of the brain shows a large infarction in the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) with midline shift. What is the most important thing to do?

options.A: Decompressive craniectomy

question_text: An elderly patient was admitted after a cardiac arrest and is now in the ICU. He is intubated, sedated, and given muscle relaxants. His pupils are non-reactive, and there is no motor response. What should be done next?

options.A: Perform an EEG
female patient post subarachnoid hemorrhage (SVD) presented with headache, visual field deficit, and suspected SIADH. With blood pressure low below 90, what is the diagnosis?
female patient diagnosed with cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) was admitted to the ICU and then deteriorated. A CT scan showed brain edema. What is in favor of hypertonic saline over mannitol?

question_text: When should a patient with Guillain-Barré syndrome be admitted to the ICU?

options.A: Rapid progression of weakness
brain CT shows coup contrecoup injury (left frontal and right temporal bleed). What is the mechanism of injury?

question_text: What is the difference between mannitol and hypertonic saline?

options.A: Decrease intracranial pressure (ICP)
options.D: Different effects on serum sodium levels

question_text: What is the most important predictor of outcome in cardiac arrest?

options.A: Duration of CPR
options.D: Initial rhythm at time of arrest

options.A: Less than 3% risk of infection.
options.B: Infection improved if the catheter changed every 5 days.

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the duration of effect between hypertonic saline and mannitol?

options.A: The effects of hypertonic saline typically last longer than those of mannitol.
options.B: The effects of mannitol typically last longer than those of hypertonic saline.
options.C: Both have the same duration of effect.
options.D: Neither has a significant duration of effect.

options.A: patient came with high blood pressure and a picture of PRESS syndrome. What is the management?

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding mannitol and hypertonic saline in the management of increased intracranial pressure (ICP)?

options.A: Both agents improve red blood cell rheology.
options.B: Both agents can cause metabolic acidosis.
options.C: A rebound exacerbation of increased ICP may occur after stopping a continuous infusion of either agent.
options.D: Both agents reduce cerebral edema by decreasing blood-brain barrier permeability.

options.A: vague scenario describes a patient with no history available, brought to the ER with decreased level of consciousness and fever. A CT scan of the brain and CSF analysis are normal. What should be done next?

question_text: In a case of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), the patient is found to have hyponatremia, high urine sodium, and high osmolarity. What is the appropriate treatment?

options.A: Fluid restriction

question_text: What is the most important predictor of outcome in cardiac arrest?

options.A: Duration of CPR

question_text: What is the best predictor for a patient in a coma (not considering brain death or time)?

options.A: Etiology
